Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic Studies on Rare and Novel Marine Alkaloids
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Gary Sulikowski of the Department of Chemistry at Vanderbilt University to develop synthetic routes to structurally novel and rare marine alkaloids isolated from marine sponges. This work provides efficient methods to access marine natural products for biomedical study. The chemistry developed during the course of these studies has a broad relevance in areas ranging from the pharmaceutical, chemical, and biotechnology industries to basic biological and chemical research endeavors. The marine natural products of interest possess unique molecular structures with minimal information on their biological properties and potential as therapeutic leads. Studies include the synthesis of upenamide, halicyclamines, xestocyclamine and haliclonin A marine alkaloids. The chemical synthesis of these natural products enables deeper investigation into their biological properties and a foundation for use as therapeutic agents for the treatment of cancer and microbial infections. In addition, the project provides excellent training of graduate and undergraduate students for entry into the pharmaceutical and chemical industry.


In each proposed chemical synthesis, new transformations are incorporated into multi-step synthetic schemes enabling the assembly of not only the marine alkaloids of interest but advance nitrogen heterocycle synthesis broadly. The use of bromomaleic anhydride as a dienophile in stereoselective Diels-Alder reactions is featured in each proposed total synthesis. The products of the key cycloaddition reaction are advanced to complex polycyclic structures by employing reactions that take advantage of key stereochemistry and functionality emerging from the initial Diels-Alder reaction.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this proposal are to develop chemical syntheses of two complex and rare marine natural products. While these natural products have shown activity against suppressing the growth of tumor and malaria cells, their further study is not possible as they are no longer available from marine sources. In addition, these natural products have unique and complex molecular structure with no readily identifiable pathway to their assembly by chemical synthesis. Thus, they present an opportunity for students to obtain deep and significant training and education in the art and practice of organic synthesis. Two senior graduate students pursuing their PhD in chemistry are now approaching the completion of the chemical synthesis of these two natural products, xestocyclamine and bielschowskysyin. In the course of their studies they have examined mutliple synthetic routes and in the course of these studies employed a broad range of chemical reactions. They also developed key scieintific skills of persistance, organization, analysis, patience and cooperation. They also developed an understanding of rigor and reproducibility in science. We anticipate the completion of these two natural products in quantity sufficient to enable their further biological study.  The process of total synthesis of these natural products will thus not only confirm their assigned molecular strucutures, but also thier reported biological activity. Perhaps the most important products of this research will be the training and education of two scientists trained in the practice of chemical synthesis and drug development.


Last Modified: 03/19/2020
Modified by: Gary Sulikowski
